question_title: Which party will win the most seats in the 2026 Nepali House of Representatives election?
summary: The 2026 Nepal House of Representatives election (March 5) is a genuinely competitive multi-party race. Nepali Congress is the most likely winner of the most seats, benefiting from: (1) being the largest party in 2022 with 89 seats and strong organizational depth across all 165 constituencies, (2) the FPTP system favoring established parties with deep local networks, (3) the left-wing vote being split three ways (CPN-UML, NCP, RSP), and (4) new younger leadership under Gagan Thapa. CPN-UML is the second most likely despite strong anti-incumbency from Oli's forced resignation during Gen Z protests. RSP, boosted by Balen Shah's merger and Gen Z momentum, is a serious contender but faces a massive gap from 20 seats (2022) to becoming the largest party, with limited rural reach. The new Nepali Communist Party (Maoist Centre merger) is an untested entity. No formal polling data or prediction markets are available.

factors.description: Nepali Congress won most seats in 2022 (89/275) and has organizational depth across all 165 FPTP constituencies - FPTP systems strongly favor parties with deep local networks
Left-wing vote split 3 ways (UML, NCP, RSP/anti-establishment) benefits centrist NC in FPTP constituencies where plurality wins
Gen Z protest anti-incumbency affects BOTH NC and UML (they were in governing coalition together), partially negating NC's structural advantage
CPN-UML has strongest anti-incumbency (Oli was PM forced to resign), reducing its chances relative to 2017 when it won 121 seats
RSP significantly strengthened by merger with Balen Shah (hugely popular mayor) and Kulman Ghising, plus Gen Z protest momentum
RSP limited rural reach - analysts explicitly warn appeal concentrated in urban areas, and Nepal is predominantly rural. Going from 20 to 90+ seats is historically rare.
NCP (Maoist Centre merger with 9 leftist factions) could consolidate ~45 seats worth of left-wing base, but party mergers in Nepal have historically been messy
NC new leader Gagan Thapa is younger and may partially address youth anti-incumbency sentiment, Deuba (aging establishment figure) opted out
